title: Translation guide allows Americans and English to understand each other | Metro News
text:
Jimmy Nsubuga for Metro.co.uk Wednesday 15 Feb 2017 5:14 pm The same words mean different things in the UK and US (Picture: GrammerCheck) 
We might share a language with the United States but sometimes we get confused about the way they spell stuff and use certain words. 
Most people understand the difference between spellings like colour (UK) and color (US). 
But not everyone knows certain words have different meanings, which could leave them embarrassed if they use the wrong one. 
Luckily Grammar Check has created an infographic that shows the different use of 63 nouns. 
MORE: Man born with severe disabilities after incestuous rape fights for compensation Click to enlarge: British v Americans (Picture: Grammer Check) 
For example, rubber in the UK is the white object that erases pencil marks but in the United States it’s a condom. 
Chips also mean something else in the states, and football isn’t the real version over there as well. 
The difference use trousers is also something you need to remember as you may end up without underwear if you tell someone in the US you want pants. 
MORE: Behold the winning dogs from the Westminster Dog Show Click to enlarge: British v Americans (Picture: Grammer Check) 
If you’re travelling ask for a taxi instead of a cab and put your stuff in the trunk rather than the boot. 
Once you’ve got to your hotel you’ll need to take an elevator up to your room and not a lift. 
And if you’re complaining at that point because of the different words you have to remember you’ll be spitting out your pacifier and not your dummy. Click to enlarge: British v Americans (Picture: Grammer Check)
